awd_titl_txt: Characterization and Prediction of Viral Capsid Geometries
awd_abstract_narration:
Viruses are the most abundant biological entity on the planet and play a crucial role in the evolution of organisms and the biogeochemistry of Earth. Closely related viruses, however, can have very dissimilar genomes, complicating integration of knowledge acquired from the study of independent viruses, and limiting prediction of the characteristics and potential threats of emerging viruses. Viruses, however, conserve a few structural properties that could help circumvent this problem. Most viruses store their infective genetic material in a protein shell called a capsid. The capsid self-assembles from multiple copies of the same (or similar) proteins, and most capsids display icosahedral symmetry. This architecture optimizes the interaction of proteins and the volume available to store the viral genetic information. This research project hypothesizes that viruses have evolved a limited set of replication strategies to specialize and exploit the reduced number of geometrical templates capable of forming icosahedral capsids. This, in turn, may have constrained the number of three-dimensional configurations adopted by capsid proteins, providing a mechanistic rationale for the existence of viral structural lineages. This hypothesis will be tested by analyzing and comparing hundreds of viruses from multiple different viral families using novel mathematical methods. Confirming this hypothesis will offer a quantitative framework to study viral evolution and open the door to design of generic antiviral strategies targeting viruses in the same structural lineage.

Only ten protein folds have been identified among major capsid proteins of viruses that form icosahedral capsids. These folds define viral lineages that group viruses that can be genetically unrelated and infect hosts from different domains of life. This limited number of folds contrasts with the vast genetic diversity of viruses. The existence of these folds across the virosphere, however, remains unknown. Here, it is hypothesized that there is a direct relationship between the viral replication strategy of each viral lineage, the icosahedral lattice of the capsid, and the fold of capsid proteins. The hypothesis will be tested by developing a database that will include the viral replication, protein fold, and capsid lattice of five hundred viruses that have been reconstructed at high or medium molecular resolution. Voronoi tessellations and protein-protein interaction lattices will be obtained to identify computationally the icosahedral lattice associated to each virus. Additionally, molecular measurements of the reconstructed capsids will be obtained to establish allometric relationships for at least one viral lineage, facilitating the prediction of icosahedral capsid properties from genomic information. The new icosahedral framework will be also extended to obtain new sets of elongated capsids, which represent the second most abundant type of capsid. The methods will be disseminated online for use by viral structure researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Characterization and prediction of viral capsid geometries 

General description. Viruses store their infective genetic material in a protein shell called the capsid, built from multiple copies of the same protein, the major capsid protein. However, little is known about the relationship between the protein sequence of major capsid proteins and the size and shape of the viral capsids they form. Studying this relationship is essential to elucidate how viral capsids have evolved and adapted across environments and identify molecular properties that could be used as antivirals that target the capsid. A significant obstacle is that major capsid proteins display little sequence similarity across different viruses. To circumvent this problem, in this award, we proposed a mathematical framework that builds on the observation that capsid proteins display a limited number of conserved three-dimensional configurations (protein folds) despite their vast sequence diversity. This key insight allowed us to build mathematical models to predict the architecture of viral capsids directly from the amino-acid sequence of the major capsid protein, opening a new door of possibilities. More importantly, we accomplished this research while training an interdisciplinary group of talented scientists.

The bulk of our research focused on the study of capsids built from major capsid proteins displaying the HK97-fold. This protein fold builds icosahedral capsids of viruses infecting organisms across the three domains of life, including the most abundant viruses on the planet, tailed phages, which infect prokaryotes. We analyzed high-resolution structures of HK97-fold capsids available in public databases and identified conserved structural properties across capsid sizes packaging genomes ranging from 15,000 to more than 500,000 base pairs. This allowed us to establish an allometric theoretical model relating the viral genome length with the icosahedral capsid architecture with a 90% accuracy. We combined this model with bioinformatics methods to analyze environmental sequences predicting the presence of HK97-fold viral capsids smaller than any structures observed among isolated viruses, filling a gap in the evolution of tailed phages. This model also allowed us to predict the capsid architecture of isolated tailed phages, generating a library extensive enough to train machine learning algorithms that predicted the architecture of viral capsids from the amino acid composition of the major capsid protein. This approach sparked collaborations that helped investigate the capsid properties of the most frequent virus in humans, which was surprisingly undetected until very recently.

To expand these results to other viral groups that rely on alternative capsid protein folds, we developed new geometrical and computational biophysical methods to characterize how the protein fold impacts the organization of proteins in the capsid. Our quasi-rigid domain decomposition method, pyCapsid, captured how the amino acids in the capsid are organized in mechanical units. These mechanical units depend strongly on the capsid size and the protein fold. More importantly, we showed that they represent a proxy to infer the protein complexes responsible for initiating the disassembly of viral capsids.

Finally, the results above focused on icosahedral capsids, encompassing about 90% of the capsids in the virosphere. However, key viruses, like HIV, adopt structures with less symmetry. To this end, we were able to develop a new mathematical approach, the triangular-path framework, which was able to use the disclinations responsible for closing the protein shell to generate the discrete landscape of symmetrical and non-symmetrical structures including the conical architectures associated with HIV.

Summary outcomes. (Intellectual merit) In this grant, PI Luque developed mathematical approaches for the geometrical characterization of capsids, predicting capsids from their genome and generating mathematically asymmetric capsids, like those observed for HIV. The research produced ten publications, including five led by the PI's group and four from collaborations (Brown et al., 2024; Cobarrubia et al., 2021; George et al., 2021; Hufsky et al., 2022; Lee et al., 2022; Luque et al., 2020; Papudeshi et al., 2023; Podgorski et al., 2023; Silveira et al., 2021, 2023). (Broader Impacts) The project supported and trained nine graduate students, including two doctoral students in computational sciences, one in Biology, and five master students in mathematics, physics, and computational sciences. It also supported eight undergraduate students in mathematics, physics, and biology. The research was disseminated in twenty-five venues, including ten international conferences, five local conferences, and ten national and international invited university seminars. The mathematical and computational methods were shared in five GitHub repositories. The bioinformatics tool pyCapsid was released on GitHub, deployed as a Python package in PIP and Conda, and made accessible in Colab without requiring installation. A GitHub page was also deployed to include accessible online documentation.
